author: By Rachel Sherman
title: The Woman Who Sold the World’s Most Expensive Dinosaur
description: Phyllis Kao, an auctioneer at Sotheby’s, captivated audiences when she sold the fossil of a stegosaurus for $44.6 million.
content: The $44.6 million stegosaurus, the most valuable fossil ever sold at auction, wasn’t the only thing that caught the attention of viewers mesmerized by a 15-minute bidding war at Sotheby’s on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Balk
title: Kimberly Guilfoyle’s Convention Sequel
description: Four years ago, her volume seemed to draw the most attention. This year, the crowd roared back.
content: Four years ago, Kimberly Guilfoyle delivered a dark, high-decibel address to the Republican National Convention that made her the subject of derisive jokes from pundits and late-night comedians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick
title: When the Taliban Took Kabul, She Fled, and Made a New Life in New York
description: Nargis Baran was a rising legal star in Afghanistan. She became a target once the government fell.
content: The night Kabul fell to the Taliban, a young lawyer named Nargis Baran was holed up in her apartment there, scrolling through news reports in disbelief. Then her boss called.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Will Higginbotham and Jake Michaels
title: Telling Hawaii’s Stories, One Hand-Carved Surfboard at a Time
description: As a kid in Kauai, the waves were his home. Today, Leleo Kinimaka pours his native knowledge and passion into one-of-a-kind creations that double as works of art.
content: Leleo Kinimaka grew up in Kauai, where the Pacific Ocean provided routine and rhythm to his days. “I’d wake up and I’d go surfing all day, maybe swim or canoe,” he recalled. “I’d only come home for lunch.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: The Trump Campaign’s Theory of Victory
description: Tim Alberta discusses why Trump’s campaign managers are increasingly confident they’re going to win by a landslide this November.
content: The Trump campaign isn’t just expecting to win this election; it’s expecting to win it in a landslide. And top Trump campaign officials were feeling that confident even before Joe Biden’s disastrous debate performance. So what’s their strategy to achieve the blowout they’re imagining? And is their confidence justified?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri
title: Deputy Fatally Shot Woman Over Pot of Hot Water, Records Show
description: The deputy, Sean Grayson of Illinois, is charged with murder and has been fired. A review of the investigation did not find the use of deadly force “justified.”
content: An Illinois sheriff’s deputy charged with murder in the death of a 36-year-old woman shot her in the face in an exchange over a pot of water and advised his partner against rendering medical aid, according to court papers filed by prosecutors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: It’s Time for Democrats to Hold Hands and Jump
description: Those who want a new presidential nominee need to go public.
content: Ever since President Biden’s calamitous debate last month, many Democrats who’ve lost faith in his candidacy have been frozen, fearing mutually assured destruction. They want Biden to step aside, but they worry that if they call on him to leave the race and he refuses, he’ll be left even weaker against Donald Trump than he is right now. “The worst of all worlds is if half of the members come out for him withdrawing, either in individual press conferences or even as a group, but then he doesn’t do anything,” one member of Congress told me Wednesday, speaking on condition of anonymity because the issue is so sensitive.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: In This Tale of a Medieval Pandemic, There’s Fun to Be Had
description: Set during the plague in 14th century Italy, Netflix’s “The Decameron” finds dark humor in a group of nobles and their servants trying to survive.
content: “The Decameron,” a new limited series, opens in Florence, Italy, in 1348. As bells toll peacefully over the rooftops, a raven lands on a window ledge, and peers around inquisitively before being struck by a stone hurled by a young boy as he yells, “Food.” The raven splats to the ground, dead, not far from the body of a shoeless man, also dead. “Mom, I got a chicken,” the boy calls out. Cheery music announces a title card: “The Black Plague.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David A. Fahrenthold, Glenn Thrush, Campbell Robertson, Adam Goldman and Aric Toler
title: A Blind Spot and a Lost Trail: How the Gunman Got So Close to Trump
description: Even though local police were on the lookout for a suspicious man, critical minutes ticked by, allowing a would-be assassin to slip past, a Times analysis found.
content: About an hour before a gunman let loose a volley of bullets that nearly assassinated a former president, the law enforcement contingent in Butler, Pa., was on the verge of a great policing success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Same-Sex Couples in South Korea Win Landmark Rights Ruling
description: The country’s Supreme Court said same-sex couples qualify for dependent coverage under the national health insurance, a decision that could have wider ramifications.
content: In a landmark ruling for gay rights in South Korea on Thursday, the country’s Supreme Court ruled that same-sex couples qualify for the national health insurance’s dependent coverage, a decision that rights activists hoped could pave the way for legalizing same-sex marriage in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Pelosi, Long Fixated on Winning, Is in No Mood to Lose With Biden
description: The former speaker has been marshaling her knowledge of the political map, polling data and fund-raising information to press her case with President Biden that his re-election is in serious doubt.
content: Nancy Pelosi is all about winning. Regarded by many as her party’s most ruthless tactician, she fought her way to the top of the Democratic leadership in the House, won the majority not once but twice and retained her speakership by putting down a rebellion from younger Democrats demanding she pass the torch to a new generation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stephen Castle
title: Russia Threat Reaches ‘Across Europe,’ U.K. Leader Tells Summit
description: More than 45 European leaders, including President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, met in England on Thursday. Fears over the continent’s security loomed large.
content: The venue was an opulent 18th-century palace, the birthplace of Winston Churchill. The guests included more than 45 of Europe’s leaders. And King Charles III was on hand to host a reception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: U.K. Failed in Handling of Covid Pandemic, Inquiry Finds
description: The British authorities prepared for the wrong pandemic, with an outdated plan overly focused on influenza, an official investigation reported.
content: Britain’s government “failed” the country’s citizens in its handling of the coronavirus pandemic, a damning report from an official public inquiry said on Thursday, partly because officials had prepared for “the wrong pandemic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Alter
title: Keanu Reeves Wrote a Book. A Really Weird One.
description: What if the star of “The Matrix” worked with a sci-fi novelist to tell the story of an 80,000-year-old warrior who can rip people’s arms off but struggles with loneliness?
content: Keanu Reeves doesn’t know exactly where the idea came from, but one day — sometime around the release of “John Wick: Chapter 2,” starring Keanu Reeves, and before he started shooting “The Matrix Resurrections,” also starring Keanu Reeves — he imagined a man who couldn’t die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Slagle
title: A Vegetable Lover’s Guide to the Grill
description: These five easy recipes and tips turn savory charred vegetables into fresh, filling main dishes.
content: When the summer sky softens and the grill’s embers flicker, dinner anticipation builds — especially when vegetables are what’s over the coals, curled in smoke. As their colorful outsides singe and their plump bodies slump, vegetables’ vibrant selves become substantial, rich and nuanced. Sugars caramelize, edges char, a whisper of smoke appears. The grill can create satisfying vegetarian meals by sizzling out moisture and teasing out deep, dark flavors. And yet a plate of grilled vegetables does not a meal make.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Late Night Taunts Former Critics Who Changed Their Minds About Trump
description: J.D. Vance and Nikki Haley, among other Republicans at the convention, seem to have gotten over their reservations about the former president.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Tim Alberta
description: The July 18, 2024, episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.”
content: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today’s episode with Tim Alberta. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Charles Homans, Asthaa Chaturvedi, Eric Krupke, Michael Benoist, Rachel Quester, Lynsea Garrison, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell, Diane Wong, Rowan Niemisto, Pat McCusker, Alyssa Moxley and Chris Wood
title: Trump 2.0: He’s Never Sounded Like This Before
description: How the former president’s message has changed, and what that means for the country.
content: In a special series leading up to Election Day, “The Daily” will explore what a second Trump presidency would look like, and what it could mean for American democracy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: As Many South Koreans Shun Marriage, Two Women Try to Redefine Family
description: Hwang Sunwoo and Kim Hana, who are single and live together, say South Korea’s laws should reflect the alternative unions that many of its people have chosen.
content: The event was to celebrate and discuss the book written by Hwang Sunwoo and Kim Hana, both 47, about their life together as single women in South Korea. But a man in the audience was there to offer criticism. He told the two women that they were making the country’s birthrate, already the world’s lowest, even worse. Their book, he argued, would encourage other women to follow suit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Trump Says ‘I Got Lucky’ in Surviving Assassination Attempt, Video Shows
description: A clip first aired by PBS shows Donald Trump addressing a gathering in Milwaukee and discussing the shooting a few days earlier: “God was with me.”
content: Former President Donald J. Trump mused to supporters at a private event held near the Republican National Convention on Wednesday about his luck in surviving an attempted assassination.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Suzanne Nossel Is Heartened by ‘Liberalism as a Way of Life’
description: Alexander Lefebvre’s new book is a ‘call to action about what we are trying to defend, and why,’ says the head of PEN America, which has been pummeled with disputes about speech, activism and Israel.
content: What books are on your night stand?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Bob Newhart, 94, Dies; Soft-Spoken Everyman Became a Comedy Star
description: He was a show-business neophyte when he stammered his way to fame in 1960. He went on to star in two of TV’s most memorable sitcoms.
content: Bob Newhart, who burst onto the comedy scene in 1960 working a stammering Everyman character not unlike himself, then rode essentially that same character through a long, busy career that included two of television’s most memorable sitcoms, died on Thursday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 404, July 19, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan
title: At R.N.C., Senators Berate Secret Service Director Over Assassination Attempt
description: The lawmakers wanted answers about security lapses at the Trump rally in Pennsylvania on Saturday.
content: Republican senators, including a member of the Senate’s leadership, accosted the director of the Secret Service in a suite at the Republican National Convention on Wednesday night, demanding that she resign or provide a full explanation for the security lapses that led to the near-miss assassination attempt against former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Biden Appears to Begin Considering Dropping Out, People Close to Him Say
description: Also, lawmakers call Secret Service’s mistakes inexcusable. Here’s the latest at the end of Thursday.
content: Several people close to President Biden said today that they believe he has begun to accept the idea that he may not be able to win in November and may have to drop out of the race. His shift comes after top Democrats, including Nancy Pelosi, told Biden that they are pessimistic about his chances of beating Donald Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Missouri Supreme Court Clears Release of Woman Who Spent 43 Years in Prison
description: Sandra Hemme, 64, was sentenced to life in prison in 1981 for the killing of a library worker. Her case was recently overturned after new evidence established her innocence.
content: A woman who has served 43 years in prison may soon be freed after Missouri’s highest court on Thursday overruled an effort to keep her incarcerated even though her murder conviction was overturned last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Nicholas Nehamas
title: Why Republicans Keep Calling Kamala Harris the ‘Border Czar’
description: The misleading phrase is meant to underscore one of the thorniest issues in her portfolio: immigration.
content: As Democrats tangle over the re-election prospects of President Biden, Republicans at their national convention this week have trained some of their most intense criticism on Vice President Kamala Harris.
source.name: The New York Times

description: When a man obsessed with woodblocks began to do business with a man obsessed with medical antiques, their relationship flowered — until it soured.
content: Earl Washington loves wood.

description: The Ohio senator officially accepted the Republican vice-presidential nomination.
content: Greetings, Milwaukee. My fellow Americans and my fellow Republicans, my name is J.D. Vance, from the great state of Ohio.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: Dig at Meloni’s Height Could Cost Reporter in Italy 5,000 Euros
description: A lawsuit that Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni won is one of several she has filed against critics. Press-freedom groups say it is a concerning practice.
content: A judge in Milan has found an Italian journalist guilty of defaming Italy’s prime minister, Giorgia Meloni, and ordered her to pay damages of 5,000 euros, or about $5,500, as well as court costs, the defendant’s lawyer said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: W.N.B.A. Players, Bargaining Power Soaring, Seek Expert Advice on Labor Deal
description: With the league’s popularity rising, players have never had more leverage when it comes to issues like salaries, travel accommodations and revenue sharing.
content: W.N.B.A. players have never had more leverage than they have right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Astead W. Herndon, Anna Foley, Caitlin O'Keefe and Elisa Gutierrez
title: Lee Greenwood and the Soundtrack of Donald Trump
description: The country star on “God Bless the U.S.A.” and the man he wants back in the White House.
content: Lee Greenwood’s “God Bless the U.S.A.” has become former President Donald J. Trump’s unofficial theme music on the campaign trail. Here at the Republican National Convention in Milwaukee, the song was performed live by none other than Mr. Greenwood himself, as Mr. Trump walked into the arena on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Dear The New York Times Learning Network,
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz and Adriana Loureiro Fernandez
title: Losing Hope, Venezuelans Vow to Leave Their Country if Maduro Wins
description: As many as one-third of Venezuelans would consider migrating if the country’s authoritarian leader is given another six years in power in an election set for July 28, one poll showed.
content: A young opposition activist planning to trek through seven countries and a perilous jungle to reach the United States. A journalist ready to abandon everything to build a new life abroad. A lawyer in her 60s, fearful that her last daughter is about to leave.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carmen Gray
title: Why This Star of Georgian Film Isn’t Showing His New Movie in Georgia
description: The director Levan Akin is worried that his latest film, “Crossing,” will inflame tensions around L.G.B.T. visibility in the post-Soviet nation.
content: When Levan Akin’s movie “And Then We Danced,” a romance between men in a Georgian folk-dance troupe, premiered at Cannes in 2019, it became a festival hit and later an Oscars submission. But when it screened in Georgia later that year, the movie’s combination of traditional Georgian culture and gay love sparked violent protests from conservative groups.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Shane Goldmacher and Maggie Haberman
title: How Trump Dominated His Own Party on a New G.O.P. Platform
description: Donald Trump and his team displayed a ruthless efficiency in the process of making a platform, confiscating delegates’ cellphones and stifling dissent and even debate.
content: Donald J. Trump long ago decided he wanted a very different Republican Party platform in 2024. The delegates who arrived in Milwaukee early last week before the Republican National Convention, with grand plans of drafting a sweeping document of party principles, quickly found out just how determined he was.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher F. Schuetze
title: Germany Promised to Step Up Militarily. Its Budget Says Differently.
description: After Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Chancellor Olaf Scholz vowed a revolution in defense strategy. But the math is not adding up.
content: Two-and-a-half years after Chancellor Olaf Scholz vowed to overhaul Germany’s military, his government’s proposed budget for 2025 calls for only a modest increase in defense spending.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Daniel Politi
title: The Catholic President Who’s ‘Almost’ Jewish
description: Javier Milei has developed a public devotion to Judaism unusual for a leader of a predominantly Roman Catholic country.
content: President Javier Milei of Argentina is a Catholic who leads Pope Francis’ native country.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Like the TARDIS in “Doctor Who,” Kareem Ayas’s puzzle travels through time and space.

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: Takeaways From Day 3 of the Republican Convention
description: Senator J.D. Vance denounced “Wall Street barons” and illegal immigration as the convention’s previous unity message shifted to more aggressive attacks on President Biden.
content: The penultimate night of the Republican National Convention belonged to the vice-presidential nominee, J.D. Vance.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Max Lakin
title: Beyond Outlaw: New Paths for Aging Taggers
description: At Lehmann Maupin, exhibitions of new work pushing the form of street art forward, from San Francisco’s Barry McGee and Osgemeos, the Brazilian artists he inspired.
content: Street art is in a funny place. More than 50 years since its invention as the urgent, unruly markings of kids scrawling their names on walls and the flanks of subway cars, it has evolved into a worldwide language and commercial behemoth — from a position outside the mainstream to one in its center. Its progenitors, having reached late middle age, are still searching for ways to push the form forward, even if that way moves beyond its improvisatory and outlaw mode into something tidier and more well mannered.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John White, Wendy Dorr, Diane Wong and Rachel Sherman
title: Colman Domingo Finds Brotherhood in ‘Sing Sing’
description: “We made this film as if it was going to be our last.”
content: Rachel Sherman brings us behind the scenes at a screening of the film “Sing Sing” at the correctional facility of the same name in Ossining, N.Y. The film’s cast was mostly made up of nonprofessional actors who were formerly incarcerated and had been part of a rehabilitation theater program inside the prison. Sherman spoke with the film’s stars, the Oscar-nominated actor Colman Domingo and Clarence “Divine Eye” Maclin, about what it was like to play these roles — and in Maclin’s case, to return to the prison where he was incarcerated for 17 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike McIntire
title: The Irreconcilable Versions of J.D. Vance in ‘Hillbilly Elegy’
description: Even before the Republican vice-presidential nominee aligned himself with Donald Trump, contradiction was central to his rags-to-riches biography.
content: Much has been made of the political pirouette J.D. Vance executed to secure the embrace of Donald J. Trump, a man he once called “cultural heroin” before seeking his endorsement for the Senate and, Wednesday night, accepting the Republican nomination to be his vice president.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Teddy Rosenbluth
title: Executives Depart Cassava, Maker of Disputed Alzheimer’s Drug
description: The chief executive and a lead scientist stepped down weeks after a federal grand jury filed fraud charges against a research collaborator.
content: Two top officials at Cassava Sciences — a small pharmaceutical company in Austin, Texas, embroiled in years of controversy over a proposed Alzheimer’s drug — have resigned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Netflix Adds 8 Million Subscribers
description: Shows like “Bridgerton” and “The Roast of Tom Brady” performed well for the streaming service, which now has 278 million subscribers worldwide.
content: Netflix added eight million subscribers in its last quarter, the streaming company said in its earnings report on Thursday, bringing its global subscription base to 278 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni and Maggie Haberman
title: For Sidelined Giuliani, a Tumble Is an Unsubtle Metaphor
description: Rudolph W. Giuliani — indicted, disbarred and bankrupt — has no speaking slot at the convention, but he is nevertheless making the rounds in Milwaukee.
content: The third night of the Republican National Convention was kicking off in Fiserv Forum on Wednesday and Rudolph W. Giuliani sat by himself across the street, poring over blown-up printouts of New York Post articles he had highlighted with a red marker as if they were pages of a scholarly text.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Jim Rutenberg
title: Tucker Carlson, Ousted by Fox, Roars Into Milwaukee as a Top Trump Ally
description: After time away from the spotlight, the right-wing host is increasingly welcomed by Trump’s inner circle. He also made a surprise visit to Fox’s convention studio.
content: All of a sudden, Tucker Carlson has roared back to the forefront of Republican politics.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Hunter Biden, Citing Trump’s Classified Documents Ruling, Seeks Dismissal of Cases
description: Mr. Biden’s legal team pointed to a decision by a federal judge in Florida, who ruled that the special counsel in Mr. Trump’s case, Jack Smith, had been unconstitutionally appointed.
content: Hunter Biden asked a federal court in Delaware on Thursday to toss out his conviction in his gun case, citing the dismissal of charges against former President Donald J. Trump in his classified documents case in Florida.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Even This Tinder Executive Thinks It’s Good to Meet I.R.L.
description: Melissa Hobley believes in the power of dating apps, but she’s been moonlighting as an old-fashioned matchmaker for over a decade.
content: It might seem odd that Melissa Hobley is a real-life matchmaker who is working with 50 to 100 singles around the globe at any given time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: Peter Buxtun, Who Exposed Tuskegee Syphilis Study, Dies at 86
description: A Public Health Service employee, he turned whistle-blower after learning of decades-long research involving hundreds of poor, infected Black men who were left untreated.
content: Peter Buxtun, a whistle-blower who in 1972 exposed a 40-year government experiment to track the effects of syphilis in Black men in Alabama — who were neither told that they had the disease nor offered treatment — died on May 18 in Rocklin, Calif., near Sacramento. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aishvarya Kavi
title: Justice Dept. Sues Contractor Over Sexual Abuse of Migrant Children
description: Southwest Key, the Texas-based nonprofit that is the largest provider of housing for unaccompanied minors who arrive at the southern border, has faced federal scrutiny before.
content: The Justice Department has sued Southwest Key Programs, the nation’s largest operator of shelters for unaccompanied migrant children, accusing its employees of repeatedly subjecting minors in its care to sexual abuse and harassment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noel Murray
title: The ‘Newhart’ Finale Was One of Bob Newhart’s Boldest TV Moments
description: The finale has become so famous in part because it offered a rare moment of real surprise from a taped prime-time television sitcom.
content: Open any search engine you like and type in these words: “best TV finales.” Scroll through the dozens — heck, hundreds — of articles written about which shows really “stuck the landing,” delivering the kind finish that fans still talk about.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What to Know About California’s Covid Surge
description: There are only a few states where Covid is spreading more.
content: Editor’s note: Starting next week, California Today will have a new look. author: By Jen Murphy
title: A 12-Minute Workout to Build Foot Strength
description: Five exercises a few times a week can make a big difference for how you walk and run.
content: Much like how the network of muscles around the hips, pelvis and back act like scaffolding for the spine, the tiny muscles within the feet are responsible for supporting the arch, absorbing load and keeping you stable when you walk or run.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatrice Loayza
title: ‘Widow Clicquot’ Review: Champagne Mami
description: This muddled film, based on a true story, chronicles the origins of the French champagne house Veuve Clicquot.
content: In the age of fizzy corporate biopics, “Widow Clicquot” — which chronicles the origins of the French champagne house Veuve Clicquot — has a couple of things going for it. Set in the 1800s around the Napoleonic Wars, the film, based on a true story, is boosted by the historical sweep and feminist credentials.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Regulars Mourn Neary’s, an Old-Time Bar That’s Closing
description: The Irish bar was opened in Manhattan 57 years ago. The building on East 57th Street has been sold.
content: Good morning. It’s Thursday. Today we’ll say goodbye to a real-life New York bar where everybody knows your name, even if you’re new in town. We’ll also get details on a move to mandate air-conditioning for tenants.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Trunsky
title: Lee Greenwood’s ‘God Bless the U.S.A.’ Has Become a Trump Rally Anthem
description: The country star answered the call to perform the song during the former president’s first public appearance after surviving an assassination attempt.
content: Lee Greenwood’s song “God Bless the U.S.A.” has been former President Donald J. Trump’s fanfare since he became the leader of the Republican Party, embracing its status as an anthem in Grand Old Party politics dating back 40 years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Hollywoodgate’ Review: Inside the Taliban
description: In a frustrating documentary, the journalist Ibrahim Nash’at shows the Taliban after American troops left Afghanistan.
content: There is no question that the director Ibrahim Nash’at faced tremendous danger in shooting “Hollywoodgate,” but the risks required to make this documentary also highlight its limitations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Genevieve Glatsky and Gray Beltran
title: Why Does Venezuela’s President Appear on the Ballot 13 Times?
description: President Nicolás Maduro will appear over and over again on Venezuela’s presidential ballot. That is by design, government critics say.
content: “We haven’t seen anything similar to this,” said Staffan Darnolf of the International Foundation for Electoral Systems, a group outside Washington that advises more than 30 countries on electoral operations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni
title: Pressure Builds on Netanyahu as Visit to Washington Nears
description: A planned speech to Congress by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has made clear the serious divisions he faces back home.
content: World leaders are pushing for a cease-fire agreement. Protesters are taking to the streets across Israel. And families of hostages are pleading with their country’s leader to just make a deal for their release.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: E.C.B. Leaves Rates Unchanged but Keeps Door Open for September
description: The central bank left its key deposit rate at 3.75 percent as inflation in the eurozone is expected to fluctuate throughout the rest of the year.
content: European Central Bank policymakers held interest rates steady on Thursday, as they reiterated their cautious approach to cutting rates as inflation bumps around above the bank’s target.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cara Buckley
title: Solving Problems With Susan Solomon
description: She played a crucial role in fixing the ozone hole, and has thoughts on climate change.
content: It’s been an especially intense week, with election-related stress and political divisiveness only increasing. So, it seemed like a good time to hear from someone who has demonstrated how people can come together to fix huge problems and who has also played a crucial role in helping remediate a global threat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik
title: Friday Briefing: U.S. Presidential Race at a Crossroads
description: Plus, security failures at the Trump rally.
content: The U.S. presidential race has reached a pivotal moment. Donald Trump is poised to formally accept the Republican presidential nomination in an arena packed with supporters, less than a week after he survived an assassination attempt. His opponent, President Biden, is recovering from Covid-19 at his beach house as calls for him to drop out grow louder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth P. Vogel

author: By Megan Conway
title: A Masterpiece of 20th-Century Sculpture That You Can Wear Around Your Neck
description: This fall, the French fashion house Celine will release a miniature version of a work by the artist Jean Arp — in the form of a pendant.
content: In 1952, the German-French artist Jean Arp made several trips to Greece, where he encountered the ideas of Claudius Ptolemy, the Greco-Roman astronomer, mathematician and geographer best known for his maps of the stars, which date to the second century A.D. Arp had helped found the radical Dada art movement in Zurich in 1916 and went on to become a leading Surrealist, but by this stage of his career, he was most preoccupied with the forms of the natural world — a fascination that he recognized in Ptolemy’s work. Some years later, back at the artist’s studio just outside of Paris, this discovery would inform Arp’s “Ptolémée” series of abstract sculptures, including “Ptolémée II” (1958), a roughly three-foot-tall biomorphic bronze that is widely considered to be among his masterworks. If Ptolemy hoped to reveal the contours of the universe in maps and treatises, Arp, who died in 1966 at 79, sought to render them in solid, three-dimensional form.

content: “My Lady Jane,” whose eight-episode first season is available now, on Amazon, seems to be in the vein of “The Great” or “Bridgerton,” irreverent historical fiction with aggressively contemporary mores and scores. But it is perhaps better understood as a fantasy comedy because not only does it break with history, it breaks with reality: It is Tudor palace intrigue with shape-shifting, a joyful and breathless more-more-more. A lot of “Jane” adheres, happily, to genre conventions, but it is done with a well-pitched playfulness. Even the stained glass in so many of the backgrounds has a funfetti color scheme.

title: 6 New Books We Recommend This Week
description: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.
content: History is written by the winners, the saying goes, and if there’s a theme to this week’s recommended books it might be that a little digging often reveals more to the story. Jessica Goudeau’s “We Were Illegal” uses the scrim of her own family tree to look at Texas’ long tradition of self-mythology; Edward O’Keefe’s “The Loves of Theodore Roosevelt” pulls the curtain on America’s most famously macho president to highlight the women who advised and influenced him; and Howard Markel’s “Origin Story” complicates our understanding of Charles Darwin’s “Origin of Species” and the toll it took on his well-being. Also up: a history of reality TV, a novel about an emergency room worker and a quicksilver collection of essays about reading and other pursuits by the Book Review’s poetry columnist, Elisa Gabbert. Happy reading. — Gregory Cowles

title: Homewares Inspired by Hunting Tools and Sea Creatures

content: The central Italian region of Umbria — with its unspoiled landscapes and ancient Roman ruins — has long been a source of inspiration for artists; in the 15th century, the region even gave rise to a namesake movement that counted the Renaissance painters Pietro Perugino and Raphael as members. It’s against that backdrop that the Babini family — who also own the Hospitality Experience, a hotel group, and the Place of Wonders, a foundation dedicated to preserving traditional Italian craftsmanship — recently opened Borgo dei Conti, a 40-room resort perched on the grounds of a former medieval fortress about a half-hour drive from Perugia. Inside the property’s original neo-Gothic villa are preserved frescoes and wood-beamed coffered ceilings along with Etruscan terra-cotta floor tiling and furniture covered in fabrics handwoven at a nearby textile atelier. Between meals at Cedri, a fine-dining restaurant placed in a former limonaia (lemon greenhouse), and L’Osteria del Borgo, an all-day trattoria serving Neapolitan pizzas, guests can visit the wellness spa — complete with saunas, a salt room and an outdoor solarium — or visit the Italian-style gardens of the surrounding 40-acre park. author: By Seth Kugel
title: Help! We Had to Sleep in the Hotel’s Breakfast Room. We Would Like a $215 Refund.
description: A couple arrived in New York after midnight, and a failed “contactless check-in” process and M.I.A. customer service made their hotel room inaccessible.
content: Last September, my husband and I flew to New York City and headed to the Ridge Hotel on the Lower East Side to spend a few days before a cruise. Since the Ridge had “contactless check-in,” we had received two codes to get in the front entrance and our room. When we arrived after midnight, we had no problems getting into the hotel with the first code. But we couldn’t get into our room with the second code. There were no staff on duty, so we called the hotel’s number. But the woman who answered could not help and subsequent calls went to voice mail. I also sent messages through the Booking.com app, the online travel agency with which we made the reservation, but the staff there couldn’t solve the issue. So we spent the night in the hotel’s breakfast room, where the restroom also required a code that we did not have. The next morning, the hotel staff sent an apologetic message with the right code, and promised us a refund for that night, about $215. But we never got the money, even though the hotel insists they returned it to Booking. Can you help? Roberta, Boise, Idaho
